revision.text:
{{multiple issues| {{more footnotes|date=October 2013}} {{underlinked|date=October 2013}} {{Citation style|date=October 2013}} }} '''Contemporary society''', according to social and political scientists, is characterised by at least three fundamental directions: * '''increasing human interconnection''' through a network of relationships that is progressively covering the whole planet; * '''the pace and depth of the evolution of human ways of life''' determined by technological innovation represent an absolute novelty in human history; * the scale of '''anthropological and ecological transformation''' due to the interaction between [[evolutionary factor]]s (social, cultural, economic, and technological) has no historical precedent.
These presentations are the result of a number of fundamental changes that are irreversibly transforming our daily lives, our way of thinking and perceiving the world and our way of living together. Among these fundamental changes are: improvements in life conditions, life expectancy, literacy and gender equality; changes in domestic and international political institutions; and the breakdown of natural equilibria.
==Improvement of life conditions== The UN estimates that, at the beginning of the 20th century, about 60% of the world population lived in conditions of extreme poverty. In 1981, 40% of the world population lived extreme poverty. In 2001, the percentage had been halved to 20%. Several developing countries, in particular in Sub-Saharan Africa, still suffer from social and economic backwardness, but life conditions have significantly improved in most regions of the world, in particular in Asia. The overall improvement in life conditions and the role of technologies now available have contributed to increase [[gross domestic product]] per capita by one and a half times in less than half a century (1960–2005), with peaks of over eight times in Eastern Asia. Only in a few countries, concentrated in Sub-Saharan Africa, growth of per capita income has been very slow.
==Life expectancy== In 1960, the average [[life expectancy]] of the world population was 50 years. Forty-five years later, in 2004, life expectancy had improved by over 30% to 67 years. Improvements in health care and the reduction in child mortality have led to a jump forward in middle-income countries, where life expectancy is now over 70 years. In high-income countries life expectancy is now over 80 years, extending well beyond the traditional length of working life, causing social and economic problems. It has led to people having an extra 4 hours of free-time during working days.<ref>television{{clarify|date=July 2016|reason="television" is ambiguous; be more specific.}}</ref>
==Literacy and gender equality== The ability to read and write is next to universal: in 2004, 80% of adult men and 73% of adult women had basic literacy skills. Of great social importance is the rapid growth of female school enrolment and the increasing presence of women in the labour market. These deep changes constitute a primary driver of economic growth in developing countries. Female literacy has great consequences in terms of fertility. When female school enrollment and employment rates increase, fertility rates decline rapidly and tend to stabilise around the natural rate of reproduction of 2.1 children per women (see E. Todd, "After the Empire"). Several demographers believe that, as a consequence, world population will stabilise over the next few decades, at a level compatible with the resources of the planet [reference].
==Spread of communication technologies== The world population has a number of "passive" (broadcasting) communication technologies (radio, television) that cover the whole globe. Moreover, a large portion of the population uses "active" communication technologies (telephone, internet). Internet connections are expanding rapidly: in 2004 there were 140 Internet users every 1000 inhabitants (according to data from the "International Communication Union"). The spread of information and communication technologies (ICT) is remodelling the material fundamentals of society. The sociologist [[Manuel Castells|Castells]] believes that these technologies have started a revolution of the productive structures of society and of daily life.
The new communication technologies represent a critical instrument to obtain consensus and as a result they are transforming the organisational models of the State and of politics. The power system becomes less visible but more pervasive in the way it can influence choices and ways of thinking [[Manuel Castells|M. Castells]], "Galassia Internet", Feltrinelli, 2002).
==Economic growth and evolution of political institutions== The economic success of authoritarian regimes, mainly in Asia, suggests that (at least in the short term) economic growth is independent from the democratisation of political institutions. However, economic development favours the development of democratic institutions—but only if economic growth leads to substantial changes in cultural and social structures. ([[Ronald Inglehart|R. Inglehart]], "La società postmoderna"). The "[[World Values Survey]]", which captures political values in 43 countries, shows that no country with a per capita income below the poverty line has democratic or free institutions. Almost the totality of nations with high per capita income are classified as democratic.
==Globalization== Over the last fifty years, world gross domestic product has increased by about five times, while trade has increased tenfold over the same period. These data suggests that the intensity of the commercial exchange between countries has developed faster than the overall economy. However, globalisation has gone beyond the exchange of physical commodities and it is progressively modelling also the lifestyles and consumption patterns of individuals and societies. The Swiss think-tank KOF has developed a number of globalisation indicators that show the increasing development of global individual, social and commercial networks.
==Social tension and opposition to change== New international flows have diminished the role of traditional political institutions—sometimes with negative consequences for social stability. In many societies, stability (or slow evolution) has been substituted by unstoppable and irreversible transformations. As a result, individuals and communities perceive a high degree of insecurity—insecurity that touches every aspect of their lives. Growing masses of people feel threatened by the changes that affect their material (work, income, house), psychological (personal relationships), and cultural life (with the need to continuously update knowledge and professional skills).
The social improvement of the masses—resulting from increasing literacy and income, universal means of communication and a new social role of women—has eroded the traditional role of the elites and have weakened the traditional regulatory role of the state. As the speed of social and cultural evolution sweeps away old life habits, religious beliefs, ancestral moral convictions and radicated political opinions, the anxiety towards a future that is mutating and unknown causes a cultural opposition that is at the root of fundamentalism. Opposition against new life conditions is justified also by increasing economic inequality: "the gap between the wealth of the North and that of the South of the world has increased by a multiple of five since the beginning of the 20th century" ([[:fr:Daniel Cohen (économiste)|Daniel Cohen]] {{fr icon}}, "Trois leçons sur la société postindustrielle").
==Breakdown of natural equilibria== When demographic growth is multiplied by the growth of per capita income and consumption, one can have a measure of the global impact on environmental sustainability. Demographic and economic development is endangering our current forms of civilization and social co-living and our future ability to inhabit our planet. Alternative scenarios developed by international organizations suggest the possibility of a serious breakdown of natural equilibrium unless political, scientific and economic tools are directed to a correction towards an acceptable equilibrium between humankind and with nature.

In [[sociology]], an '''industrial society''' is a society driven by the use of [[technology]] to enable [[mass production]], supporting a [[population growth|large population]] with a high capacity for [[division of labour]]. Such a structure developed in the [[Western world]] in the period of time following the [[Industrial Revolution]], and replaced the [[agrarian society|agrarian societies]] of the [[Modern history#Pre-modern|pre-modern]], [[pre-industrial society|pre-industrial]] age. Industrial societies are generally [[mass society|mass societies]], and may be succeeded by an [[information society]]. They are often contrasted with [[traditional society|traditional societies]].<ref name=slang>S. Langlois, Traditions: Social, In: Neil J. Smelser and Paul B. Baltes, Editor(s)-in-Chief, ''International Encyclopedia of the Social & Behavioral Sciences'', Pergamon, Oxford, 2001, pages 15829-15833, {{ISBN|978-0-08-043076-8}}, {{doi|10.1016/B0-08-043076-7/02028-3}}. [http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/B7MRM-4MT09VJ-4PM/2/1eb81ee3e63af98afa7a48ecacfb64a6 Online]</ref>
[[industrialization|Industrial]] societies use external energy sources, such as [[fossil fuels]], to increase the rate and scale of production.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://media.wiley.com/product_data/excerpt/98/04717398/0471739898.pdf |title=Chapter 1: Energy Fundamentals, Energy Use in an Industrial Society |website= |accessdate=2007-12-18}}</ref> The production of food is shifted to large commercial farms where the products of industry, such as [[combine harvesters]] and fossil fuel based [[fertilizers]], are used to decrease required human labor while increasing production. No longer needed for the production of food, excess labor is moved into these [[factories]] where [[mechanization]] is utilized to further increase efficiency. As populations grow, and [[mechanization]] is further refined, often to the level of [[automation]], many workers shift to expanding [[service industries]].
Industrial society makes [[urbanization]] desirable, in part so that workers can be closer to centers of production, and the [[service industry]] can provide labor to workers and those that benefit financially from them, in exchange for a piece of production profits with which they can buy goods. This leads to the rise of very large cities and surrounding [[suburb]]an areas with a high rate of [[economic activity]].
These [[urban area|urban centers]] require the input of external energy sources in order to overcome the [[diminishing returns]]<ref>{{cite journal |last=Arthur |first=Brian |title=Positive Feedbacks in the Economy |journal=[[Scientific American]] |volume=262 |pages=92–99 |date=February 1990}}</ref> of agricultural consolidation, due partially to the lack of nearby [[arable land]], associated transportation and storage costs, and are otherwise unsustainable.<ref>{{cite journal |last=McGranahan |first=Gordon |authorlink= |date=November 2003 |title=URBAN CENTERS: An Assessment of Sustainability |journal=Annual Review of Environment and Resources |volume=28 |issue= |pages=243–274 |id= |url= |accessdate= |quote= |doi=10.1146/annurev.energy.28.050302.105541 |last2=Satterthwaite |first2=David }}</ref> This makes the reliable availability of the needed energy resources high priority in industrial government policies.
Some theoreticians (namely [[Ulrich Beck]], [[Anthony Giddens]], and [[Manuel Castells]]) argue that we are located in the middle of a transformation or transition from industrial societies to [[post-industrial society|post-industrial societies]]. The triggering technology for the change from an agricultural to an industrial organisation was [[steam power]], allowing [[mass production]] and reducing the agricultural work necessary. Thus, many industrial cities have been built around rivers. Identified as catalyst or trigger for the transition to post-modern or [[informational society]] is global [[information technology]].
Some, such as Theodore Kaczynski, have argued that an industrialized society leads to [[psychological pain]] and that citizens must actively work to return to a more primitive society. His essay, ''[[Industrial Society and Its Future]]'', describes different political factions and laments the direction of technology and the [[modern world]].

revision.text:
[[File:Map of Vacation Days Around the World.png|thumb|upright=2.1|Minimum mandatory paid vacation days, normalised for a five-day workweek:
{{legend|#FFFFFF|No data}} {{legend|#e0e0e0|No mandatory vacation}} {{legend|#C7E9B4|1–5 days}} {{legend|#7FCDBB|6–10 days}} {{legend|#41B6C4|11–15 days}} {{legend|#0570b0|16–20 days}} {{legend|#225EA8|21–22 days}} {{legend|#023858|23–28 days}}
]] In the majority of nations, including all industrialised nations except the United States, advances in [[Labour law|employee relations]] have seen the introduction of statutory agreements for minimum [[Annual leave|employee leave from work]]—that is the amount of entitlement to paid vacation and public holidays. Several companies will offer contractually more time, depending on the sector. Companies and the law may also differ as to whether [[Lists of holidays|public holidays]] are counted as part of the minimum leave. Disparities in national minimums are still subject of debate regarding [[work-life balance]] and perceived differences between nations. These numbers usually refer to full-time employment, part-time workers may get a reduced number of days. In most countries, public holidays are paid and usually not considered part of the annual leave. Also, in most countries there are additional paid leave benefits such as [[parental leave]] and [[sick leave]] that are not listed here. == Methodology == For the purpose of comparison, the paid vacation column has been normalised to a five-day workweek. For instance, a calendar day is divided by seven and multiplied by five, while a six-day workweek day is divided by six and multiplied by five. The paid vacation column gives the minimum mandatory vacation days for an employee who has one year of service with the same employer. In some countries, the public holidays are strictly bound to the calendar dates, so if they happen on Saturday or Sunday, they are "lost" for the particular year. As a result, the average number of paid extra free days can be lower than the table specifies. For example, in the Czech Republic, where the official number of paid public holidays is 13, the average number of public holidays during working days in the years 2000–2016 was only 8.9 days. In other countries, the public holidays which happen on Saturday or Sunday are moved to the nearest Monday or Friday such as in the United Kingdom or the United States. ==Countries== {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! width=120 | Country and flag ! class="unsortable" | Minimum annual leave ! style="width:150px;" data-sort- type="number"| Paid vacation days
(five-day workweek){{cite news|last1=Ghosheh|first1=Naj|title=Working conditions laws report 2012: A global review|url=http://www.ilo.org/wcmsp5/groups/public/---ed_protect/---protrav/---travail/documents/publication/wcms_235155.pdf|accessdate=11 September 2014|agency=International Labour Organization|date=2013}}{{cite web|url=http://www.doingbusiness.org/data/edata/ExploreTopics/labor-market-regulation|title=Employing Workers|last=|first=|date=|website=Doing Business: Measuring Business Regulations|publisher=World Bank Group|accessdate=1 October 2014}}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ! style="width:120px;" data-sort- type="number"| Paid public holidays{{cite web|title = Worldwide National Public Holidays for 2016, 2017, 2018, 2019, 2020|url = http://www.qppstudio.net/publicholidays.htm|website = www.qppstudio.net|access-date = 2016-02-13|last = qppstudio.net}}{{cite web|title = Employment law by country|url = http://www.fedee.com/kb/countries|website = www.fedee.com|access-date = 2016-02-14|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20160222064808/http://www.fedee.com/kb/countries|archive-date = 2016-02-22|dead-url = yes|df = }} ! style="width:120px;" data-sort- type="number"| Total paid leave (five-day workweek) |- |{{flag|Afghanistan}} |Employees are entitled to 20 days recreational leave and [[Public holidays in Afghanistan|15 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|title=Travail Legal Database: Working Time in the Asian Region|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/travmain.sectionReport1?p_lang=en&p_structure=2&p_sc_id=1368&p_sc_id=1694&p_sc_id=1390&p_sc_id=1717&p_countries=REG3|website=Travail: Conditions of Work and Employment Programme|publisher=International Labour Organization|accessdate=16 September 2014}} | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"|35 |- |{{flag|Albania}} |Employees are entitled to 20 days of annual leave and [[Public holidays in Albania|12 paid public holidays]].{{Cite book|title = European Social Charter (revised): Albania, Armenia, Belgium, Bilgaria, Cyprus, Estonia, Finland, France|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=e19_13snDgUC|publisher = Council of Europe|date = 2007-01-01|isbn = 9789287163387|language = en|first = Comité européen des Droits|last = sociaux|page = 19}} | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|12 | style="text-align:center;"|32 |- |{{flag|Algeria}} |The paid annual leave is calculated on the basis of 2 and 1/2 days per month of work. The total duration of the leave cannot, however, exceed 30 calendar days per year.{{cite web|title=Travail Legal Database: Working Time in the Africa Region|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/travmain.sectionReport1?p_lang=en&p_structure=2&p_sc_id=1368&p_sc_id=1694&p_sc_id=1390&p_sc_id=1717&p_countries=REG1|website=Travail: Conditions of Work and Employment Programme|publisher=International Labour Organization|accessdate=1 October 2014}} Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Algeria|11 paid public holidays]]. | style="text-align:center;"|30 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|41 |- |{{flag|Andorra}} |Workers are entitled to 31 calendar days of paid leave after one year of employment. Before that, entitlement to leave is calculated at a rate of 2.5 days for every month worked. One period of leave must last two weeks or more to allow an uninterrupted rest period.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=32vwQRE70jMC|title=European Social Charter (revised): European Committee of Social Rights, Conclusions (2010)|first=Council of Europe: European Committee of Social|last=Rights|date=6 October 2011|publisher=Council of Europe|via=Google Books}} Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Andorra|14 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bopa.ad/bopa/027073/Pagines/GH20151023_09_22_50.aspx|title=Decret del 21-10-2015 pel qual s’aprova el calendari laboral corresponent a l’any 2016.|publisher=}} | style="text-align:center;"|31 | style="text-align:center;"|14 | style="text-align:center;"|45 |- |{{flag|Angola}} |The period of annual leave for workers is of 22 days per year, not including weekends, complementary weekly rest days and holidays in this calculation. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Angola|11 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|title = Lei de trbalho Angolana. O que não deve esquecer|url = http://www.meusalario.org/angola/main/lei-geral-do-trabalho/lei-de-trbalho-angolana.-o-que-nao-deve-esquecer|website = www.meusalario.org|access-date = 2016-02-15}} | style="text-align:center;"|22 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|33 |- |{{flag|Antigua and Barbuda}} |The length of the annual leave for an employee who has successfully passed his probationary period is at least one day per month of employment; 12 days per year of work performed. Every employees is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Antigua and Barbuda|11 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|title=Travail Legal Database: Working Time in the Americas Region|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/travmain.sectionReport1?p_lang=en&p_structure=2&p_sc_id=1368&p_sc_id=1694&p_sc_id=1390&p_sc_id=1717&p_countries=REG5&p_start=1&p_increment=10|website=Travail: Conditions of Work and Employment Programme|publisher=International Labour Organization|accessdate=16 September 2014}} | style="text-align:center;"|12 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|23 |- |{{flag|Argentina}} | 14 calendar days (from 0 to 5 years seniority), 21 calendar days (from 5 to 10), 28 calendar days (from 10 to 20) and 35 calendar days (from 20). Every employees is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Argentina|11 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161005130519/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/latinamerica/argentina-english-old.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|21 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|31 |- |{{flag|Armenia}} |Generally, the duration of annual leave is 20 working days. Extended annual leave up to 25 working days is granted to certain categories of employees whose work involves great nervous, emotional and intellectual strain and professional risk.{{cite web|title=Travail Legal Database: Working Time in the European Region|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/travail/travmain.sectionReport1?p_lang=en&p_structure=2&p_sc_id=1368&p_sc_id=1694&p_sc_id=1390&p_sc_id=1717&p_countries=REG4&p_start=1&p_increment=10|website=Travail: Conditions of Work and Employment Programme|publisher=International Labour Organization|accessdate=16 September 2014}} Every employees is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Armenia|12 paid public holidays]].{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=32vwQRE70jMC|title=European Social Charter (revised): European Committee of Social Rights, Conclusions (2010)|last=Rights|first=Council of Europe: European Committee of Social|date=2011-10-06|publisher=Council of Europe|isbn=9789287171474|page=84|language=en}}{{cite web|url=https://rm.coe.int/CoERMPublicCommonSearchServices/DisplayDCTMContent?documentId=090000168048abfb |title=Documents |website=rm.coe.int |format=PDF}} | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|12 | style="text-align:center;"|32 |- |{{flag|Australia}} |For each year of service with his or her employer, an employee is entitled to a minimum of 4 weeks of paid annual leave, unless the employee is a shiftworker, in which case he or she is entitled to a minimum of 5 weeks of paid annual leave. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Australia|10 to 13 paid public holidays]] depending on the state and territory. [[Long service leave]], which varies by jurisdiction, is also available to long standing employees.{{cite web|title=Leave|url=http://www.fairwork.gov.au/Leave|website=Fair Work Obudsman|publisher=Australian Government|accessdate=16 October 2014}} | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|30 |- |{{flag|Austria}} |If the employee has less than 25 years of service, he is entitled to 25 days of annual leave. If the employee has 25 years or more, he is entitled to 30 days of annual leave. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Austria|13 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|url = http://www.arbeiterkammer.at/beratung/arbeitundrecht/Urlaub/So_viel_Urlaub_bekommen_Sie.html|title = Ihr Anspruch auf Urlaub|date = |accessdate = |website = Arbeiterkammer|publisher = |last = |first = }}[https://web.archive.org/web/20161005125553/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/europe/austria-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|25 | style="text-align:center;"|13 | style="text-align:center;"|38 |- |{{flag|Azerbaijan}} | Employees are entitled to a minimum of 21 basic calendar days of annual leave. Skilled employees, experts and senior employees are entitled to 30 basic calendar days of annual leave. Additional 2 days accrue on top of basic vacation every 5 years.{{cite web|url = http://www.ilo.org/dyn/natlex/docs/WEBTEXT/46039/65055/E94AZE02.htm|title = Azerbaijan: Law on Leaves (Unofficial translation)|date = |accessdate = 16 October 2014|website = Natlex|publisher = International Labour Organization|last = |first = }} Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Azerbaijan|19 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161224094120/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/russia/azerbaijan-english] | style="text-align:center;"|21 | style="text-align:center;"|19 | style="text-align:center;"|40 |- |{{flag|The Bahamas}} |14 days after 1 year employment, 21 days after 7 years of employment. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in the Bahamas|10 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|url=https://www.bahamas.gov.bs/wps/wcm/connect/65b3d851-5769-4914-9f2e-235171ac8033/Employment+(Amendment),+2012+DRAFT.pdf?MOD=AJPERES |title=Employment amendment |date=2012 |website=www.bahamas.gov.bs}}{{cite web|url=http://laws.bahamas.gov.bs/cms/images/LEGISLATION/PRINCIPAL/1938/1938-0015/PublicHolidaysAct_1.pdf |title=Legislation |date=1938 |website=laws.bahamas.gov.bs |format=PDF}} | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|20 |- |{{flag|Bahrain}} |An employee who has been in the service of an employer for at least one year is entitled to a paid annual leave not less than thirty days, with an average of two and a half days for each month.{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/natlex/docs/MONOGRAPH/91026/105342/F265276925/BHR91026%20Eng.pdf |title=Monograph |website=http://www.ilo.org |format=PDF}} Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Bahrain|14 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161224100013/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/gulf-middle-east/bahrain-english] | style="text-align:center;"|22 | style="text-align:center;"|14 | style="text-align:center;"|36 |- |{{flag|Bangladesh}} |All workers except tea plantation workers are entitled to 10 days of paid casual leave in each calendar year. An adult worker is entitled to: (a) for shop, commercial or industrial establishment, factory, or road transport service industry workers – one day's paid annual leave per 18 days of work; (b) for tea plantation workers – one day's paid annual leave per 22 days of work; and (c) for newspaper workers – one day's paid annual leave per 11 days of work. Every worker is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Bangladesh|11 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161005124957/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/asia/bangladesh-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|21 |- |{{flag|Barbados}} |An employee who completes a year of employment with an employer is entitled to – (a) an annual holiday of not less than 3 weeks where he has been in the employment of that employer for less than 5 years; and (b) an annual holiday of not less than 4 weeks where he has been in the service of that employer for 5 years or more. | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| |- |{{flag|Belarus}} |The length of basic annual leave is 24 calendar days. Plus 3 calendar days might be granted in addition for long time employment. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Belarus|9 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161224100106/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/russia/belrus-english] | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|9 | style="text-align:center;"|29 |- |{{flag|Belgium}} |A worker after one year of full employment, the employee shall be entitled to: 24 working days if they work 6 days per week; and 20 working days if they work 5 days per week. Workers are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Belgium|10 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|title=Developments in collectively agreed working time 2013|website=EIROnline, European industrial relations observatory on-line|publisher=Eurofund|accessdate=26 September 2014|url = http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/eiro/studies/TN1405020S/index.htm}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20161005194839/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/europe/belgium-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|30 |- |{{flag|Belize}} |Every employee is entitled to two weeks paid leave after a year of employment. If employment is terminated after three months but before a year, the employee must be paid average vacation pay. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Belize|13 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20140819112930/http://labour.gov.bz/index.php/en/2013-02-12-02-42-04#ancla5 Labour Advice] | style="text-align:center;"|14 | style="text-align:center;"|13 | style="text-align:center;"|27 |- |{{flag|Benin}} |Unless there are more favorable provisions in collective agreements or employment contracts, the worker acquires the right to leave, to be paid by the employer, at the rate of 2 working days per month of effective service. A working days is every day other than the day of weekly rest period and holidays. Every worker is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Benin|13 paid public holidays]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/africa/benin-english%20delete.pdf |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-10-04 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161005194501/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/africa/benin-english%20delete.pdf |archive-date=2016-10-05 |dead-url=yes |df= }} | style="text-align:center;"|24 | style="text-align:center;"|13 | style="text-align:center;"|37 |- |{{flag|Bhutan}} | | style="text-align:center;"|9 | style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| |- |{{flag|Bolivia}} |There are different scales of annual leave depending on the seniority of the worker. To this respect; workers having performed from 1 to 5 years of service are entitled to enjoy 15 working days, from 5 to 10 years, 20 working days, and from 10 years onwards, 30 working days. Every worker is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Bolivia|11 paid public holidays]]. | style="text-align:center;"|15/20/30 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|26/31/41 |- |{{flag|Bosnia and Herzegovina}} |Bosnia and Herzegovina consists of 2 entities (Republic of Srpska and Federation of Bosina and Herzegovina) and one district (Brčko District). These 3 parts all have their own work laws. Both Republic of Srpska and Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina have minimum of 20 working days while number of additional days varies. In District Brčko workers have 18 days. In Republic of Srpska workers have additional 1 day for every 5 years of work at same employee and additional 2 days for religious holidays. In Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina workers have 2 paid days for religious holidays and, optionally, 2 unpaid days for religious holidays. Number of public holidays also varies in all 3 autonomous parts. In Republic of Srpska around 11, in Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina around 10 and in Brčko District around 9. Number of public holidays varies based on predominant religious group in entity. Note that Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina consists of 10 cantons of which any can have their own laws that can affect number of public holidays. | style="text-align:center;"|20-30 | style="text-align:center;"|9-11 | style="text-align:center;"|29-41 |- |{{flag|Botswana}} |Every employer is required to grant to every employee employed by him leave with basic pay at the rate of not less than 1.25 days per month. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Botswana|14 paid public holidays]]. | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"|14 | style="text-align:center;"|29 |- |{{flag|Brazil}} |The length of annual leave depends on the number of days of absence from work: 30 calendar days (22 working days, considering a 5-day workweek) when the worker was absent no more than 5 days; 24 calendar days (18 working days) when the worker was absent between 6 and 14 days; 18 calendar days (14 working days) when the worker was absent between 15 and 23 days; 12 calendar days (10 working days) when the worker was absent between 24 and 32 days. Every employee is also entitled to [[Public holidays in Brazil|7 national paid public holidays, 1 state paid holiday, and up to 4 religious municipal paid holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161224095628/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/latinamerica/brazil-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|10/14/18/22 | style="text-align:center;"|12 | style="text-align:center;"|22/26/30/34 |- |{{flag|Brunei Darussalam}} |[11] | style="text-align:center;"|7 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|18 |- |{{flag|Bulgaria}} |An employee has the right to paid annual leave in the duration of at least four weeks for each calendar year. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Thailand|13 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|url=http://protection.labour.go.th/doc/%E0%B8%AA%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%97%E0%B8%98%E0%B8%B4%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%A2%E0%B8%88%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%A5%E0%B8%B9%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%88%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%87-%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%B1%E0%B8%87%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A4%E0%B8%A9.pdf|title=Rights and Duties Employer and Employee, Labour Protection Bureau Department of Labour Protection and Welfare Ministry of Labour, Thailand|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.panwagroup.net/business/index2.html|title=Labour laws, rules, regulations in Thailand|publisher=}} | style="text-align:center;"|6 | style="text-align:center;"|13 | style="text-align:center;"|19 |- |{{flag|East Timor}} | | style="text-align:center;"|12 | style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| |- |{{flag|Togo}} |Workers are entitled to two and a half days per month. There are no legal provisions for pay on [[Public holidays in Togo|public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20160302103935/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/africa/Decentworkcheck-Togo-English.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|22 | style="text-align:center;"|0 | style="text-align:center;"|22 |- |{{flag|Tonga}} |The Tongan government is working on legislation to provide for paid vacation time.{{cite web|url=http://www.mctl.gov.to/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/Final-Draft-ERB-2013-April-20131-19Apr13.pdf|title=This website is currently unavailable.|website=www.mctl.gov.to}} | style="text-align:center;"|0 | style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| |- |{{flag|Trinidad and Tobago}} |All workers in general are entitled to 14 consecutive days holiday with pay at the expiration of each complete year. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Trinidad and Tobago|14 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/ifpdial/information-resources/national-labour-law-profiles/WCMS_158855/lang--en/index.htm|title=National labour law profile: Trinidad and Tobago|date=2011-06-17|website=www.ilo.org|language=en|access-date=2016-03-10}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20120531111327/http://rgd.legalaffairs.gov.tt/Laws2/Alphabetical_List/lawspdfs/19.05.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|14 | style="text-align:center;"|24 |- |{{flag|Tunisia}} |All workers who perform at least 1 month of work during the reference year are entitled to enjoy 1 day of leave per month with a total duration not exceeding 15 days, of which 12 will be working days. Workers are entitled to additional leave days as follows; 1 day yearly for every 5 years of work with the same employer to a maximum of 18 days. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Tunisia|6 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20160302114523/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/africa/Decentworkcheck-Tunisia-20151209-%20English.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|6 | style="text-align:center;"|16 |- |{{flag|Turkey}} |14 work days (Saturdays are counted as workdays) for 1–5 years, 20 work days for 6–15 years and 26 days for over 15 years seniority. There are a total of [[Public holidays in Turkey|14.5 paid public holiday]]s, but if these holidays fall on Sundays or other off-days of a worker, they are not carried over to the next workday.[https://web.archive.org/web/20160302110605/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/europe/Decentworkcheck-Turkey-English.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|12 | style="text-align:center;"|14.5 | style="text-align:center;"|26.5 |- |{{flag|Uganda}} |An employee, once in every calendar year, is entitled to a holiday with full pay at the rate of seven days in respect of each period of a continuous four months' service. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Uganda|13 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|title = Annual Leave, Holiday Pay, Weekly Rest Days - Uganda - Mywage.ug|url = http://mywage.ug/home/labour-laws/work-time-holiday|website = mywage.ug|access-date = 2016-02-14}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20161029111706/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/africa/uganda-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"|13 | style="text-align:center;"|28 |- |{{flag|Ukraine}} |Employees are entitled to 24 calendar days of paid annual leave.{{cite web|url=http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312277|title=Ratifications of ILO conventions: Ratifications by Convention|website=www.ilo.org|access-date=2016-03-03}} 8–11 days of National Holidays (often moved to a next working day if overlap with Saturdays or Sundays).{{cite web|url=http://zib.com.ua/ru/118507-vihodnie_dni_-_2016_kabmin_nazval_prazdnichnie_i_vihodnie_dn.html|title=Выходные дни - 2016: Кабмин назвал праздничные и выходные дни|website=zib.com.ua}} | style="text-align:center;"|18 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|29 |- |{{flag|United Arab Emirates}} |The worker shall be entitled during every year of service an annual leave of no less than the following periods: Two days for each month should the period of service of the worker be of six months at least and a year at most; Thirty days for each year should the period of service of the worker exceed one year. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in the United Arab Emirates|10 paid public holidays]].{{cite web|url=http://www.thenational.ae/business/personal-finance/how-much-annual-leave-are-uae-domestic-staff-entitled-to|title=How much annual leave are UAE domestic staff entitled to?|website=The National|access-date=2016-03-25}} | style="text-align:center;"|22 | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|32 |- |{{flag|United Kingdom}} |Employees are entitled to 28 total working days (5.6 weeks) of annual leave. These often include the [[Public holidays in the United Kingdom|8 public/bank holidays]] which otherwise would be unpaid. Many employers will offer 25 days of paid annual leave in addition to the 8 recognised bank holidays. Paid time off can increase with years of service. For example, an employee might accrue one extra day for every 5 years of service up to a maximum of 30 days paid leave, exclusive of bank holidays. Some employers will allow staff to purchase or sell holiday, usually a maximum of 5 days. Part-time workers are entitled to the same amount of leave but this is calculated on a pro-rata basis.{{cite web|title=Holiday entitlement|url=https://www.gov.uk/holiday-entitlement-rights/entitlement|website=Gov.UK|publisher=United Kingdom Government|accessdate=15 October 2014}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20161029045044/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/europe/uk-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|8 | style="text-align:center;"|28 |- |{{flag|United States}} |There is no federal or state statutory minimum paid vacation or paid public holidays. Paid leave is at the discretion of the employers to its employees.{{cite web|url=http://www.dol.gov/dol/topic/workhours/vacation_leave.htm|title=Vacation Leave|date=9 December 2015|publisher=}}[https://web.archive.org/web/20161029044942/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/northamerica/usa-english.pdf] According to the [[Bureau of Labor Statistics|US Bureau of Labor Statistics]], 77% of private employers offer paid vacation to their employees; full-time employees earn on average 10 vacation days after one year of service.{{cite web|title = Paid leave in private industry over the past 20 years : Beyond the Numbers: U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics|url = http://www.bls.gov/opub/btn/volume-2/paid-leave-in-private-industry-over-the-past-20-years.htm|website = www.bls.gov|access-date = 2016-02-08|first = Robert W. Van|last = Giezen}} Similarly, 77% of private employers give their employees paid time off during public holidays, on average 8 holidays per year.{{cite web |title= 2015 Holiday Schedules |work= Society for Human Resource Management |accessdate= December 24, 2014 |date= November 10, 2014 |quote= A majority of employers (94-97%) plan to observe New Year's Day, Memorial Day, Labor Day, Thanksgiving and Christmas in 2015. Because Independence Day falls on a Saturday, 60% of organizations will be closed on Friday, July 3, the day before Independence Day. |url= http://shrm.org/research/surveyfindings/articles/pages/SHRM-2015-Holiday-Schedules.aspx }} Some employers offer no vacation at all.{{cite web |title = 2014 Employee Benefits: An Overview of Employee Benefits Offerings in the U.S.|work = Society for Human Resource Management|first1 = Christina|last1 = Lee|first2 = Alexander|last2 = Alonso|first3 = Evren|last3 = Esen|first4 = Jennifer|last4 = Schramm|first5 = Yan|last5 = Dong|date = June 2014|pages = 28–32|url = http://shrm.org/Research/SurveyFindings/Documents/14-0301%20Benefits_Report_TEXT_FNL.pdf|accessdate = December 24, 2014}} The average number of paid vacation days offered by private employers is 10 days after 1 year of service, 14 days after 5 years, 17 days after 10 years, and 20 days after 20 years.{{cite web|url=http://www.bls.gov/ncs/ebs/benefits/2011/ownership/private/table23a.htm|title=Paid vacations: Number of days by service requirement|publisher=}} | style="text-align:center;"|0 | style="text-align:center;"|0 | style="text-align:center;"|0 |- |{{flag|Uruguay}} |All workers, in the private sector and civil servants, are entitled to at least 20 days of paid annual leave. Workers who have worked in the same company, are entitled to an additional day of leave for every four years of seniority. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Uruguay|5 paid public holidays]].Ministerio de Trabajo y Seguridad Social (Uruguay) - Régimen de Licencia [https://web.archive.org/web/20090320002136/http://www.mtss.gub.uy/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1595&Itemid=1595] | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|5 | style="text-align:center;"|25 |- |{{flag|Uzbekistan}} | | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| |- |{{flag|Vanuatu}} |Every employer shall grant to an employee who has been in continuous employment with the same employer for: (a) a period of 1 to 6 years - annual leave on full pay at the rate of 1.25 working days per month for each year of employment; or (b) a period of 7 to 19 years - annual leave on full pay at the rate of 1.75 working days per month for each year of employment. There are no legal provisions for pay on [[Public holidays in Vanuatu|public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20160406163815/http://vcci.com.vu/wp-content/uploads/2014/02/3.4-factsheet-sundays-and-public-holidays.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"|0 | style="text-align:center;"|15 |- |{{flag|Venezuela}} |Workers are entitled to enjoy 15 days of paid annual leave in the first year plus one day for each year of service with the same employer up to a maximum of 15 extra days. | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"| | style="text-align:center;"| |- |{{flag|Vietnam}} | Employees working in normal working conditions are entitled to 12 working days after every 12 months of employment. This entitlement increases by one additional day of leave for every five years of employment in an enterprise or with an employer. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Vietnam|10 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161029045327/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/asia/vietnam-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|12 | style="text-align:center;"|10 | style="text-align:center;"|22 |- |{{flag|Yemen}} |Workers shall be entitled to leave of not less than 30 days with full pay for each year of effective service, to be calculated on the basis of at least two-and-a- half days for each month. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Yemen|15 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20160302111202/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/gulf-middle-east/Decentworkcheck-Yemen-English.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|22 | style="text-align:center;"|15 | style="text-align:center;"|37 |- |{{flag|Zambia}} |Employees are entitled to two days of paid holidays in respect of each period of one month's service. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Zimbabwe|11 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161028153110/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/africa/zambia-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|20 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|31 |- |{{flag|Zimbabwe}} |An employee is entitled to one twelfth of the employee's qualifying service in each year of employment, subject to a maximum accrual of ninety days of paid vacation leave. Employees are also entitled to [[Public holidays in Zimbabwe|11 paid public holidays]].[https://web.archive.org/web/20161028153245/http://www.wageindicator.org/documents/decentworkcheck/africa/zimbabwe-english.pdf] | style="text-align:center;"|22 | style="text-align:center;"|11 | style="text-align:center;"|33 |} ==See also== *[[Annual leave]] *[[Parental leave]] *[[List of holidays by country]] ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *[http://www.businessinsider.com/what-its-like-to-have-nationally-mandated-work-vacation-2017-10/ 6 people from around the world share what it's like to have nationally mandated work vacation]. part of the set of 740+ outlines listed at [[Portal:Contents/Outlines]].
Wikipedia outlines are a special type of list article. They make up one of Wikipedia's content navigation systems
See [[Wikipedia:Outlines]] for more details. Further improvements to this outline are on the way ...--> {{Other uses|Society (disambiguation)}} The following [[Outline (list)|outline]] is provided as an overview of and topical guide to society:
'''[[Society]]''' – group of people sharing the same geographical or virtual territory and therefore subject to the same political authority and dominant cultural expectations. Such people share a distinctive [[culture]] and [[institutions]], which characterize the patterns of [[social relations]] between them. Large societies typically develop [[social stratification]] and [[dominance hierarchy|dominance patterns]] among its subgroups. A given society may be described as the sum total of social relationships among its members. The branch of science that studies society is [[sociology]].
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==What ''type'' of thing is a society?==
A society can be described as all of the following: * [[System]] – ** [[Social system]] – * [[People]] – ** [[Social group]] – *** [[Community]] –
==Types of societies==
* [[Human]]ity – the entire human race. As a whole, it can be viewed as one great big society.
===In anthropology: by methods of subsistence===
* [[Pre-industrial society]] ** [[Hunter-gatherer society]] – ** [[Pastoral society]] – ** [[Horticulture#Anthropology|Horticultural society]] – ** [[Agrarian society]] – *** [[Feudal society]] – * [[Industrial society]] – * [[Post-industrial society]] –
===In sociology and political science === * by political structure: ** [[Band society]] – ** [[Tribe]] – ** [[Chiefdom]] – ** [[Civilization]] *** [[State (polity)|State]] – *** [[International community]] – *** [[World community]] – * by modernity: ** [[Pre-modern#Pre-Modern|Pre-modern]] – ** [[Modernity|Modern]] – ** [[Postmodernity|Post-modern]] –
==Aspects or features of societies==
* [[Community|Communities]] ([[Outline of community|outline]]) – while a society is a type of community, it can itself comprise smaller communities. ** [[Structure and agency]] ** [[Socialization]] ** [[Sense of community]] ** [[Communitarianism]] ** [[Social capital]] ** [[Community development]] * [[Culture]] ([[Outline of culture|outline]]) – Shared culture can create sub communities of people within a society due to their shared attitudes, values, goals and practices (ref: Woodward, K., (2004) Questioning Identity: gender, class, ethnicity, Milton Keynes, The Open University). ** [[Cultural heritage]] – * [[Economy]] ([[Outline of economics|outline]]) – ** [[Economic system]] – * [[Education]] ([[Outline of education|outline]]) – * [[Government]] – * [[Identity (social science)|Identity]] – Interaction with others within our society helps shape our identity, (along with our gender, class & cultural origins), and a shared society can promote a sense of shared identity(ref: Woodward, K., (2004) Questioning Identity: gender, class, ethnicity, Milton Keynes, The Open University). * [[Infrastructure]] – ''see [[#Infrastructure|Infrastructure section]], below'' * [[Institution]]s – ''see [[#Social institutions|Social institutions section]], below'' * [[Land (economics)|Land]] – * [[Natural resource]]s – * [[People]] – * [[Politics]] ([[Outline of politics|outline]]) – * [[Social control]] – ** [[Guilt society]] – ** [[Shame society]] – * [[Social institution]] – ''see [[#Social institutions|Social institutions section]], below'' * [[Social structure]] ** [[Social order]] – ** [[Social stratification]] – * [[Technology and society]] ([[Outline of technology|outline]]) – * [[Wealth]] –
=== Infrastructure ===
[[Infrastructure]] * [[Public infrastructure]] ** [[Transportation system]]s *** Road systems **** [[Road]]s **** [[Highway]]s **** [[Street]]s **** [[Bridge]]s **** [[Tunnel]]s *** [[Public transport|Mass transit]] *** [[Airport]]s and Airways  ** [[Water supply]] and [[Water resources]] ** [[Wastewater]] management ** [[Waste management|Solid-waste treatment]] and disposal ** [[Electric power]] * Private infrastructure ** [[Personal property]] *** [[Automobile]]s *** [[Personal computer]]s ** [[Real estate]] *** [[Home]]s
=== Social institutions ===
[[Social institution]] – any persistent structure or mechanism of social order governing the behaviour of a set of individuals within a given community. The term "institution" is commonly applied to customs and behavior patterns important to a society, as well as to particular formal organizations of government and public services. * [[Family]] ** Family members – families are composed of: *** Offspring **** [[Daughter]] **** [[Son]] *** [[Parent]] **** [[Father]] **** [[Mother]] *** [[Grandparent]] ** Types of families *** [[Nuclear family]] *** [[Extended family]] ** Family related topics *** [[Home]] *** [[Human bonding]] *** [[Sociology of the family]] * [[Government]] – * [[Marriage]] and the [[family]] – * [[Religion]] ([[Outline of religion|outline]]) and religious institutions – see [[sociology of religion]]; [[civil religion]] * [[Education]]al institutions – [[school]]s ([[Preschool education|preschool]], [[Primary education|primary/elementary]], [[Secondary education|secondary]], and [[Higher education|post-secondary/higher]] – see [[Sociology of education]]) * [[Research]] community – [[Academia]] and [[University|universities]]; [[research institute]]s – see [[sociology of science]] * [[Medicine]] – [[hospital]]s and other [[health care]] institutions – see [[sociology of health and illness]], [[medical sociology]] ** [[Psychiatric hospital]]s ([[history of psychiatric institutions|history]]) * [[Law]] ([[Outline of law|outline]]) and legal system – [[court]]s; [[judge]]s; the legal profession ([[Bar (law)|bar]]) – see [[jurisprudence]], [[philosophy of law]], [[sociology of law]] ** [[Law enforcement and society]] – ** [[Criminal justice]] or penal systems – [[prison]]s – see [[sociology of punishment]] * [[Military]] ([[Outline of military science|outline]]) – ''(See also [[military sociology]]).'' ** [[Paramilitary]] – * [[Police]] forces * [[Mass media]] – including the [[news media]] ([[Television news|television]], [[newspapers]]) and the [[popular media]] – see [[media studies]] * [[Industry]] – [[business]]es, including [[corporation]]s – see [[financial institution]], [[factory]], [[capitalism]], [[division of labour]], [[social class]], [[industrial sociology]] * [[Civil society]] or [[NGOs]] – [[Charitable organization]]s; [[advocacy group]]s; [[Political party|political parties]]; [[think tank]]s; [[Virtual community|virtual communities]] <!-- :: '''''[[Economy]] and [[Business]]''''' – [[Finance]] • [[Management]] • [[Marketing]] ::'''''[[Education]]''''' – [[Academia]] • [[Academic misconduct]] • [[Homework]] • [[Learning]] • [[Pedagogy]] • [[School]] • [[Student]] • [[Study skills]] • [[Teacher]] [[Politics]] * [[Politics of present-day nations and states|Politics by country]] • [[International relations]] • [[Public administration|Public affairs]] :: '''''[[Law]]''''' – [[Criminal justice]]  -->
==Societal change==
* [[Social change]] ** [[Decadence]] ** [[Social development]] *** [[Social progress]] *** [[Technological evolution]] *** [[Sociocultural evolution]]
=== Stages of sociocultural evolution ===
[[Sociocultural evolution]] – below are listed some typical and some ''potential'' stages of progression in the evolution of cultures and societies: * Pre-civilization ** [[Hunter-gatherer]] [[band society|bands]] ** [[Social rank]] ** [[Tribe]]s ** [[Social stratification]] ** [[Chiefdom]]s ** [[Neolithic Revolution]] * [[Civilization]] ** [[Pre-industrial society]] *** [[Agrarian society]] **** Agrarian [[village]]s **** [[Town]]s **** [[City|Cities]] **** [[City-state]]s **** [[Nation-state]]s ** [[Industrial Revolution]] ** [[Modernity]] *** [[Industrial society]] ** [[Postmodernity]] *** [[Post-industrial society]] ** [[Informational Revolution]] ** [[Information society]] *** [[Digital Revolution]] *** [[Knowledge society]] ** [[Globalization]] – process by which the world is becoming more interconnected, being integrated into a unified global community, through the interchange — of world views, products, ideas and other aspects of culture — made possible by technological advancements in communication and transportation and the dissemination of knowledge those bring. ** ''[[World government]]?'' – notion of a single common political authority (global state) for all of humanity. Currently there is no worldwide executive, legislature, judiciary, military, or constitution with jurisdiction over the entire planet. The United Nations is limited to a mostly advisory role, and its stated purpose is to foster cooperation between existing national governments rather than exert authority over them. * ''[[Space colonization]]?'' – hypothetical expansion of the human race into outer space: to the moon, to other planets or moons, or in space stations. * ''[[Technological singularity]]?'' (TS) – hypothetical result that may occur if and when [[Artificial general intelligence|strong AI]] (artificial intelligence at least as smart as a human) is developed. Such AIs would be recursive, and therefore able to improve themselves (or each other) at an increasingly rapid rate to super intelligence. Technological advancements implemented by such entities would probably be so profound and come so quickly that it seems unlikely anyone could reliably forecast what such a future would be like — like a black hole, a singularity we cannot see.
===Forces of societal change=== * [[Climate change, industry and society]] – * ''[[Connections (TV series)|Connections]]'' – James Burke presented in this TV series his hypothesis that the entire gestalt of the modern world is the result of a web of interconnected events, each one consisting of a person or group acting for reasons of their own motivations (e.g., profit, curiosity, religious) with no concept of the final, modern result to which the actions of either them or their contemporaries would lead. The interplay of the results of these isolated events is what drives history and innovation. * [[Conquest (military)|Conquest]] – * [[Cooperation]] – * [[Deviance (sociology)|Deviance]] – * [[Disaster]] – * [[Economic forces]] – ** [[Economic growth]] – * [[Exploration]] – * [[Human migration]] – Migration can impact on our identity since it may be difficult to feel a sense of belonging in a new society. Human migration can also introduce new cultural values to a society, (ref: Held, D.,(2004) A globilizing world? Culture, economics and politics, London Routeledge/The Open University) * Population change ** [[Population decline]] – ** [[Population growth]] – * [[Revolution]] – * [[Social conflict]] – * [[Social disintegration]] – * [[Social movement]] – * [[Societal collapse]] – * [[Technological change]] – * [[Urbanization]] – * [[Trade]] – * [[War]] –
==History of society==
* [[Civilization#History|History of civilization]] * Society-related history ** [[Rural history]] – ** [[Social history]] – ** [[Urban history]] – * [[Sociocultural evolution]] –
==Study of society: sociology==
[[Outline of sociology]] * [[Sociology]] – scientific study of society. This social science directs methods of empirical investigation and critical analysis upon human social activity, focusing on the influence of relationships and how they affect attitudes and behaviours. Sociologists conduct research to refine the theoretical understanding of social processes, or for application to social policy and welfare. ** [[Branches of sociology]] ** [[History of sociology]]

[[File:The Earth seen from Apollo 17.jpg|thumb|right|The Earth Seen from Apollo 17]] '''Planetary consciousness''' is the idea that human beings are members of a planetary society of [[Earth]] as much as they are members of their nations, provinces, districts, islands, cities or villages.
== History == In his 1906 book ''American Character'', author [[Brander Matthews]] mentions the idea of a "league of nations" and a "planetary consciousness", believing it would be created by American politicians in the coming centuries.<ref>{{cite book | url=https://books.google.com/?id=UA2WY1GvV-oC&pg=PA187&lpg=PA187&dq=%22League+of+Nations%22+%22planetary+consciousness%22+-wikipedia#v=onepage&q=%22League%20of%20Nations%22%20%22planetary%20consciousness%22%20-wikipedia&f=false | author=Matthews, Brander | authorlink=Brander Matthews | title=American Character | page=187 | publisher=Thomas Y. Crowell & Co |date=September 1906}}</ref> Key planetary consciousness events of the 20th century include the creation of the [[League of Nations]], the signing of [[Kellogg-Briand Pact]], the creation of the [[United Nations]], and the creation of the [[Bretton Woods system]]. [[Democratic globalization]] advocate [[Abhay Kumar]] points to the [[ICANN|International Corporation of Assigned Names and Numbers]] (ICANN) board of directors election in 2000, which were conducted globally, as the first example of global democracy.<ref name=abhay>{{cite news | title=Birth of Global Democracy | author=K, Abhay | authorlink=Abhay Kumar | work=[[Times of India]] | date=21 January 2011 | url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-01-21/edit-page/28367706_1_printing-press-number-of-mobile-phones-gutenberg | accessdate=13 August 2012}}</ref> In September 2001, [[Ervin László]] and the [[Dalai Lama]] wrote an essay titled "Manifesto on Planetary Consciousness", which was adopted at a meeting at the [[Hungarian Academy of Sciences]] in Budapest.<ref name=manifesto>{{cite web | author1=László, Ervin | authorlink1=Ervin László | author2=[[Dalai Lama]] | title=Manifesto on Planetary Consciousness | publisher=WorldShift International | date=15 September 2001 | url=http://www.worldshiftinternational.org/manifesto-planetary-consciousness/ | accessdate=13 August 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120828003626/http://www.worldshiftinternational.org/manifesto-planetary-consciousness/ | archivedate=28 August 2012 | df= }}</ref> Its introduction begins:
{{cquote|text=In the closing years of the twentieth century, we have reached a crucial juncture in our history. We are on the threshold of a new stage of social, spiritual, and cultural evolution, a stage that is as different from the stage of the earlier decades of this century as the grasslands were from the caves, and settled villages from life in nomadic tribes. We are evolving out of the nationally based industrial societies that were created at the dawn of the first industrial revolution, and heading toward an interconnected, information-based social, economic, and cultural system that straddles the globe.<ref name=manifesto/>}}
[[Andreas Bummel]], CEO of the Committee for a Democratic UN, says, "The first step into the direction of a world parliament would be the establishment of a Parliamentary Assembly at the United Nations".<ref name=bummel/>
==Concept== Advocacy for the idea of planetary consciousness is based on the technological advancements made by the mankind in the fields of transport and telecommunications during the 20th century and in the first decade of the 21st century.<ref name=abhay/> Kumar claims that these technological advancements have turned the whole planet into an interdependent economic, political and communication community.<ref name=abhay/> He specifically cites the invention of the Internet and the mobile phones as key technological achievements of the 20th century which brought humans into more continuous interconnected communication.<ref name=abhay/> He believes that these inventions will lead to a second [[Renaissance]] and global democracy, just as the [[Gutenberg press]] in 1439 led to the first Renaissance, the [[Age of Enlightenment]], and [[Nation state]]s.<ref name=abhay/> Bummel describes planetary consciousness as integral, insofar as it does not conflict with other levels of [[Identity (social science)|social identity]], but instead is a holistic perspective on humanity and the planet as a whole.<ref name=bummel>{{cite journal | title=Social Evolution, Global Governance and a World Parliament | author=Bummel, Andreas | journal=[[Cadmus (journal)|Cadmus]] | date=11 April 2012 |url=http://www.cadmusjournal.org/article/issue-4/social-evolution-global-governance-and-world-parliament#13 | accessdate=13 August 2012}}</ref> Steven Kull writes that while nation states are reluctant to work cooperatively, individuals seem more willing.<ref>{{cite journal | author=Kull, Steven | title=Listening to the Voice of Humanity | journal= Kosmos Journal | issue=Spring/Summer | year= 2010 | pages=26–29}}</ref>
Author [[Shashi Tharoor]] feels that an [[Earth Anthem]] sung by people across the world can inspire planetary consciousness and [[global citizenship]] among people.<ref>[http://newindianexpress.com/nation/Indian-diplomat-pens-anthem-for-earth/2013/06/05/article1620381.ece Indian diplomat pens anthem for earth] The New Indian Express 5 June 2013</ref>
==See also== * [[Earth Anthem]] * [[Global citizenship]]

'''Risk society''' is the manner in which modern [[society]] organizes in response to [[risk]]. The term is closely associated with several key writers on [[modernity]], in particular [[Ulrich Beck]] and [[Anthony Giddens]].<ref name=BeckRiskSociety> {{cite book |author=Ulrich Beck |title=Risk Society, Towards a New Modernity |location=London |publisher=Sage Publications |year=1992 |pages=260 }} </ref> The term was coined in the 1980s and its popularity during the 1990s was both as a consequence of its links to trends in thinking about wider modernity, and also to its links to popular discourse, in particular the growing [[environmentalism|environmental concerns]] during the period.<ref>Caplan, p.7.</ref>
==Definition== According to British sociologist [[Anthony Giddens]], a risk society is "a society increasingly preoccupied with the future (and also with safety), which generates the notion of risk,"<ref>Giddens and Pierson 1998, p.209.</ref> whilst the German sociologist [[Ulrich Beck]] defines it as "a systematic way of dealing with hazards and insecurities induced and introduced by [[modernisation]] itself (Beck 1992:21)".<ref name=BeckRiskSociety />
Beck (1992:50)<ref name=BeckRiskSociety /> defined modernization as,
{{Quote box |quote = "surges of technological rationalization and changes in work and organization, but beyond that includes much more: the change in societal characteristics and normal biographies, changes in lifestyle and forms of love, change in the structures of power and influence, in the forms of political repression and participation, in views of reality and in the norms of knowledge. In social science's understanding of modernity, the plough, the steam locomotive and the microchip are visible indicators of a much deeper process, which comprises and reshapes the entire social structure." |width = 75% |align = center }}
==Background==
===Modernity and realism in science=== Beck and Giddens both approach the risk society firmly from the perspective of [[modernity]], "a shorthand term for modern society or industrial civilization... modernity is vastly more dynamic than any previous type of social order. It is a society... which unlike any preceding culture lives in the future rather than the past." (Anthony Giddens)<ref>Giddens and Pierson p.94.</ref> They also draw heavily on the concept of [[Reflexivity (social theory)|reflexivity]], the idea that as a society examines itself, it in turn changes itself in the process. In classical industrial society, the modernist view is based on assumption of realism in science creating a system in which scientists work in an exclusive, inaccessible environment.
==Implications==
===Environmental risks=== In 1986, right after the [[Chernobyl disaster]], Ulrich Beck, a sociology professor at the University of Munich, published the original German text, ''Risikogesellschaft'', of his highly influential and catalytic work (Suhrkamp, Frankfurt 1986). ''Risikogesellschaft'' was published in English as ''Risk Society: Towards a New Modernity'' in 1992. The ecological crisis is central to this social analysis of the contemporary period. Beck argued that environmental risks had become the predominant product, not just an unpleasant, manageable side-effect, of industrial society.
Giddens and Beck argued that whilst humans have always been subjected to a level of risk – such as [[natural disasters]] – these have usually been perceived as produced by non-human forces. Modern societies, however, are exposed to risks such as [[pollution]], newly discovered illnesses, crime, that are the result of the [[modernization]] process itself. Giddens defines these two types of risks as [[external risk]]s and [[manufactured risks]].<ref>Giddens, 1999.</ref> [[Manufactured risks]] are marked by a high level of [[human agency]] involved in both producing, and mitigating such risks.
As [[manufactured risks]] are the product of human activity, authors like Giddens and Beck argue that it is possible for societies to assess the level of risk that is being produced, or that is about to be produced. This sort of reflexive introspection can in turn alter the planned activities themselves. As an example, disasters such as [[Chernobyl]] and the [[Love Canal]] Crisis, public faith in the modern project has declined leaving public distrust in [[industry]], [[government]] and [[expert]]s.<ref>Giddens, 1990.</ref>
Social concerns led to increased regulation of the nuclear power industry and to the abandonment of some expansion plans, altering the course of modernization itself. This increased critique of modern industrial practices is said to have resulted in a state of [[reflexive modernization]], illustrated by concepts such as [[sustainability]] and the [[precautionary principle]] that focus on preventative measures to decrease levels of risk.
There are differing opinions as to how the concept of a risk society interacts with social hierarchies and class distinctions.<ref>Caplan, p.6.</ref> Most agree that social relations have altered with the introduction of manufactured risks and reflexive modernization. [[Risk]]s, much like [[wealth]], are distributed unevenly in a population and will influence quality of life.
[[Ulrich Beck|Beck]] has argued that older forms of class structure – based mainly on the accumulation of wealth – atrophy in a modern, risk society, in which people occupy [[social risk positions]] that are achieved through risk aversion. "In some of their dimensions these follow the inequalities of class and strata positions, but they bring a fundamentally different distribution logic into play".<ref>Beck, p.23.</ref> Beck contends that widespread risks contain a 'boomerang effect', in that individuals producing risks will also be exposed to them. This argument suggests that wealthy individuals whose [[Capital (economics)|capital]] is largely responsible for creating pollution will also have to suffer when, for example, the contaminants seep into the water supply. This argument may seem oversimplified, as wealthy people may have the ability to mitigate risk more easily by, for example, buying bottled water. [[Ulrich Beck|Beck]], however, has argued that the distribution of this sort of risk is the result of [[knowledge]], rather than wealth. Whilst the wealthy person may have access to [[factors of production|resources]] that enable him or her to avert risk, this would not even be an option were the person unaware that the risk even existed. However, Risks do not only affect those of a certain social class or place, risk is not bias and can affect everybody no matter your class, nobody is free from risk.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Risk Society: Towards a New Modernity|last=Beck|first=Ulrich|last2=Ritter|first2=Mark|publisher=Sage Publications|year=1992|isbn=978-0803983465|location=London}}</ref>
By contrast, [[Anthony Giddens|Giddens]] has argued that older forms of class structure maintain a somewhat stronger role in a risk society, now being partly defined "in terms of differential access to forms of self-actualization and empowerment".<ref>Giddens 1991, p. 6.</ref> [[Anthony Giddens|Giddens]] has also tended to approach the concept of a risk society more positively than [[Ulrich Beck|Beck]], suggesting that there "can be no question of merely taking a negative attitude towards risk. Risk needs to be disciplined, but active risk-taking is a core element of a dynamic economy and an innovative society."<ref>Giddens, ''Runaway World'', 1999, p.29.</ref>
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== * [[Pat Caplan|Caplan, Pat]] 'Introduction: Risk Revisited' in Caplan, Pat (ed) 'Risk Revisited', Pluto Press: London (2000). * Ericson, R.V. & K. Haggerty. 1997. ''Policing the Risk Society.'' Toronto: University of Toronto Press. * [[Anthony Giddens|Giddens, Anthony]] (1990) ''Consequences of Modernity''. Cambridge: Polity Press. * [[Anthony Giddens|Giddens, Anthony]] (1991) ''Modernity and Self-Identity. Self and Society in the Late Modern Age''. Cambridge: . * Giddens, Anthony and Christopher Pierson (1998) ''Making Sense of Modernity: Conversations with Anthony Giddens'' * Giddens, Anthony (1998) ''The Third Way: The Renewal of Social Democracy''. Cambridge : Polity. * [[Anthony Giddens|Giddens, Anthony]] (1999) "Risk and Responsibility" ''Modern Law Review'' 62(1): 1-10. * [[Anthony Giddens|Giddens, Anthony]] (1999) ''Runaway World: How Globalization is Reshaping Our Lives''. London : Profile. * [[Ulrich Beck]] (1992) ''Risk Society: Towards a New Modernity''. New Delhi: Sage. (Translated from the German [[:de:Risikogesellschaft|''Risikogesellschaft'']]) 1986.
==External links== * Leiss, W. [https://www.ualberta.ca/~cjscopy/articles/leiss.html Ulrich Beck, Risk Society, Towards a New Modernity]. Featured Book Reviews. ''Canadian Journal of Sociology,'' Online edition.
